content.question: If <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>1</mn> <mo>+</mo> <msup> <mi>x</mi> <mrow> <mfrac> <mn>2</mn> <mn>3</mn> </mfrac> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@425E@</annotation> </semantics> </math>, which of the following is NOT true?

choices.label: f is continuous for all real numbers.
f has a minimum at x=0.

topic.text: 2.4: Connecting Differentiability and Continuity - Determining When Derivatives Do and Do Not Exist
